elements.content: In this paper, four novel silver(I) sulfonate coordination polymers containing neutral ligands, namely, [Ag2L1(biim)2]·2H2O (1), AgL2(biim) (2), [Ag(HL3)(Pic)2]·H2O (3), and [Ag3(L3)(HL3)(4,4‘-bipy)3(H2O)2]·4H2O (4), have been synthesized [L1 = 3-carboxy-4-hydroxybenzenesulfonate, L2 = p-aminobenzenesulfonate, H2L3 = p-hydroxybenzenesulfonic acid, biim = 1,1‘-(1,4-butanediyl)-bis(imidazole), Pic = β-picoline, 4,4‘-bipy = 4,4‘-bipyridine]. For compounds 1 and 2, Ag(I) cations are bridged by biim ligands to form a one-dimensional (1D) “zigzag” chain, and L1 and L2 sulfonate ligands are not coordinated to the silver cation. Compound 3 has a dimeric structure in which two silver cations are bridged by two HL3 ligands. For compound 4, L3 ligand coordinates to a silver cation as a monodentate ligand, and Ag(I) cations are bridged by 4,4‘-bipy ligands to form a 1D chain. Compound 1 contains water dimers, while compound 4 contains water trimers. Compounds 1−3 display room-temperature photoluminescence.

Compound 1 contains water dimers, while compound 4 contains water trimers. Compounds 1-3 display room-temperature photoluminescence.

elements.content: Four coordination polymers of silver(I) sulfonates containing neutral ligand were synthesized and characterized. Three of them show one-dimensional polymeric structures that contain a polymeric chain of silver ions and neutral ligands, and one shows a discrete dimeric structure. Three compounds display photoluminescent properties.
elements.clean_text: Four coordination polymers of silver(I) sulfonates containing neutral ligand were synthesized and characterized. Three of them show one-dimensional polymeric structures that contain a polymeric chain of silver ions and neutral ligands, and one shows a discrete dimeric structure. Three compounds display photoluminescent properties.

elements.content: To design and synthesize metal−organic coordination networks (MOCNs) based on coordination bonds and noncovalent interactions (such as hydrogen-bonding interactions), the interactive information stored in the ligand, as well as the coordination geometry of the metal ions, should be taken into account. Careful selection of a suitable organic ligand containing the ability to form hydrogen bonding is helpful for constructing novel MOCNs. The -SO3 - group can adopt many bridging coordination modes, and Ag, a d10 metal, has no crystal field stabilization energy and hence no dominant geometrical preferences. Therefore, interest has recently been focused on silver(I) sulfonates by reason of their abilities to form various structures and their properties. On the basis of previous reports, the structure motif of most silver(I) sulfonates observed is a two-dimensional (2D) sheet, which is similar to that of metal phosphonates. In addition, the study of the effect of an organic group on the structures of silver(I) sulfonates has been explored by Shimizu. Some silver(I) sulfonate compounds modified by nitrogen-based ligands that display different structure motifs depending upon the presence of secondary ligands have been reported. It has also been demonstrated that existence and changes of the neutral ligands in silver(I) sulfonates can result in surprising results. However, the information on silver sulfonate coordination polymers are not yet well understood, and investigations of silver(I) sulfonates with neutral ligands are rather insufficient.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

To design and synthesize metal-organic coordination networks (MOCNs) based on coordination bonds and noncovalent interactions (such as hydrogen-bonding interactions), the interactive information stored in the ligand, as well as the coordination geometry of the metal ions, should be taken into account. Careful selection of a suitable organic ligand containing the ability to form hydrogen bonding is helpful for constructing novel MOCNs. The -SO3 - group can adopt many bridging coordination modes, and Ag, a d10 metal, has no crystal field stabilization energy and hence no dominant geometrical preferences. Therefore, interest has recently been focused on silver(I) sulfonates by reason of their abilities to form various structures and their properties. On the basis of previous reports, the structure motif of most silver(I) sulfonates observed is a two-dimensional (2D) sheet, which is similar to that of metal phosphonates. In addition, the study of the effect of an organic group on the structures of silver(I) sulfonates has been explored by Shimizu. Some silver(I) sulfonate compounds modified by nitrogen-based ligands that display different structure motifs depending upon the presence of secondary ligands have been reported. It has also been demonstrated that existence and changes of the neutral ligands in silver(I) sulfonates can result in surprising results. However, the information on silver sulfonate coordination polymers are not yet well understood, and investigations of silver(I) sulfonates with neutral ligands are rather insufficient.

elements.content: In this paper, four compounds, namely, [Ag2L1(biim)2]·2H2O (1), AgL2(biim) (2), [Ag(HL3)(Pic)2]·H2O (3), and [Ag3(L3)(HL3)(4,4‘-bipy)3(H2O)2]·4H2O (4) [L1 = 3-carboxy-4-hydroxybenzenesulfonate, L2 = p-aminobenzenesulfonate, H2L3 = p-hydroxybenzenesulfonic acid, biim = 1,1‘-(1,4-butanediyl)bis(imidazole), Pic = β-picoline, 4,4‘-bipy = 4,4‘-bipyridine], were synthesized with two aims:  one is to construct novel MOCNs and the other is to explore the effect of the neutral ligands on silver sulfonates. The chosen sulfonate ligands containing -OH and -NH2 groups have a potential for hydrogen-bonding interactions to construct new MOCNs and enhance crystal stability. The selected aromatic nitrogen bases are good neutral ligands for silver cations. Biim is a divergent bidentate ligand and commonly acts as a flexible bridging ligand. In our previous work, some coordination polymers containing biim ligand with different topologies have been reported. Therefore, biim was selected as a neutral ligand to construct novel silver sufonate coordination polymers and explore its effect on different silver sulfonate compounds. At the same time, Pic (a monodentate ligand) and 4,4‘-bipy (a divergent bidentate ligand) were employed to synthesize new silver sulfonates and study the influence of the number of coordinating atoms of the neutral ligand on the silver sulfonate compound. Compounds 1 and 2 containing the same neutral ligand show a one-dimensional (1D) polymeric structure. Although compounds 3 and 4 contain the same sulfonate anion, 3 shows a discrete dimeric structure, while 4 displays a 1D chain structure. The structures of the sulfonate anions and neutral ligands used in this work are shown in Schemes and . The work in this paper extends the previous work on silver(I) sulfonate coordination chemistry. All crystal structures have been determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, and the compounds are also characterized by IR and elemental analyses. Moreover, compounds 1−3 exhibit photoluminescent properties at room temperature.

elements.content: Physical Methods. The emission/excitation spectra were recorded on a Varian Cary Eclipse spectrometer.

elements.content: Synthesis of [Ag2L1(biim)2]·2H2O (1). To a mixture of H2L1 (0.127 g, 0.5 mmol) and NaOH (0.04 g, 1.0 mmol) in water was added AgNO3 (0.170 g, 1.0 mmol) with constant stirring, to which was added biim (0.096 g, 0.5 mmol) in water. After the sample was stirred for 10 min, the precipitate was dissolved by dropwise addition of aqueous NH3 solution. Colorless crystals were obtained from the filtrate by slow evaporation after standing in the dark for several days (75% yield). Anal. Calcd for C27H35Ag2N8O8S:  C 38.27, H 4.16, N 13.22. found:  C 38.21, H 4.13, N 13.27. IR (KBr, cm-1) 3859(w), 3741(ms), 3443(ms), 2361(vs), 2336(vs), 1700(ms), 1645(ms), 1560(ms), 1515(ms), 1467(w), 1197(w), 673(ms), 565(w), 432(w), 406(ms).

elements.content: Synthesis of AgL2(biim) (2). To a mixture of HL2 (0.173 g, 1 mmol) and NaOH (0.040 g, 1 mmol) in water was added AgNO3 (0.255 g, 1.5 mmol) with constant stirring, and a white precipitate formed. The precipitate was dissolved by dropwise addition of aqueous NH3 solution, to which was added biim (0.288 g, 1.5 mmol) in 10 mL of ethanol. Colorless crystals were obtained from the filtrate by slow evaporation after standing in the dark room for several days (78% yield). Anal. Calcd for C16H20AgN5O3S:  C 40.86, H 4.29, N 14.89. found:  C 40.75, H 4.23, N 14.96. elements.content: X-ray Crystallography. Experimental details of the X-ray analyses are provided in Table . Diffraction intensities for compounds 1−4 were collected on a Bruker Apex CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated MoKα radiation (λ = 0.71069Å). The structures were solved with the direct method of SHELXS-974 and refined with full-matrix least-squares techniques using the SHELXL-97 program5 within WINGX. Non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Analytical expression of neutral-atom scattering factors were employed, and anomalous dispersion corrections were incorporated. Further details are provided in Supporting Information.

elements.content: Selected bond distances and angles for compounds 1−4 are listed in Table . As shown in Figure , the L1 ligand in compound 1 does not show any bonding actions with silver cations; it only acts as a counteranion. There are two crystallographically unique sliver ions with different environments. Ag(1) is coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from different biim ligands with Ag(1)−N(2A) and Ag(1)−N(3) distances being 2.114(3) and 2.113(3) Å. These silver cations are bridged by biim ligands to form a 1D infinite polymeric chain structure as shown in Figure a. Ag(2) is also coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from different biim ligands with both Ag(2)−N(6) and Ag(2)−N(7A) distances being 2.102(3) Å. Moreover, the Ag(2)−Ag(2A) distance of 3.340(1) Å is shorter than the van der Waals contact distance for Ag−Ag of 3.40 Å; therefore, a Ag−Ag bond exists between two silver cations. The N(6)−Ag(2)−N(7A), N(6)−Ag(2)−Ag(2A), and N(7A)−Ag(2)−Ag(2A) angles are 168.46(11), 118.86(8), and 72.65(8)° respectively. Two chains of alternate Ag(2) cations and biim ligands are connected by a Ag−Ag interaction to form 1D ladder structure as shown in Figure b. Thus, both a polymeric chain structure and a polymeric ladder structure exist in compound 1, and the polymeric chains and ladders are arranged in a parallel mode (see Figure S1, Supporting Information).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Selected bond distances and angles for compounds 1-4 are listed in Table . As shown in Figure , the L1 ligand in compound 1 does not show any bonding actions with silver  cations; it only acts as a counteranion. There are two crystallographically unique sliver ions with different environments. Ag(1) is coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from different biim ligands with Ag(1)-N(2A) and Ag(1)-N(3) distances being 2.114(3) and 2.113(3) Å. These silver cations are bridged by biim ligands to form a 1D infinite polymeric chain structure as shown in Figure a. Ag(2) is also coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from different biim ligands with both Ag(2)-N(6) and Ag(2)-N(7A) distances being 2.102(3) Å. Moreover, the Ag(2)-Ag(2A) distance of 3.340(1) Å is shorter than the van der Waals contact distance for Ag-Ag of 3.40 Å; therefore, a Ag-Ag bond exists between two silver cations. The N(6)-Ag(2)-N(7A), N(6)-Ag(2)-Ag(2A), and N(7A)-Ag(2)-Ag(2A) angles are 168.46(11), 118.86(8), and 72.65(8)° respectively. Two chains of alternate Ag(2) cations and biim ligands are connected by a Ag-Ag interaction to form 1D ladder structure as shown in Figure b. Thus, both a polymeric chain structure and a polymeric ladder structure exist in compound 1, and the polymeric chains and ladders are arranged in a parallel mode (see Figure S1, Supporting Information).

Water clusters have been extensively studied both theoretically and experimentally. A variety of water clusters, [(H2O) n , n = 2−10] found in a number of crystal hosts, have been characterized and display different configurations. However, water clusters in silver(I) sulfonate frameworks have not been studied in detail. It is interesting to note that (H2O)2 dimers exist with OW···OW distances of 2.804(4) Å. As shown in Figure , two lattice water molecules in compound 1 arrange themselves to form a hydrogen-bonded water dimer, and this supramolecular water dimer is associated with the L1 ligand by hydrogen bonds. The geometrical parameters of the water dimer and its association with L1 ligand are provided in Table . For comparison, the corresponding values in regular ice, in liquid water, and in the vapor phase are 2.74, 2.85, and 2.98 Å, respectively. Interestingly, two oxygen atoms of the water dimer have different coordination numbers of three and one, respectively. OW2 donates hydrogen bonds to OW1, which in turn donates to carboxylate oxygen atoms. OW1 behaves as an acceptor as well as a donor, while OW2 behaves as a donor only. Therefore, OW1 has a normal three-coordinate configuration. Two L1 ligands and two water molecules are organized through hydrogen bonds in an approximate quadrangle with four oxygen atoms each at corner.
elements.clean_text: Water clusters have been extensively studied both theoretically and experimentally. A variety of water clusters, [(H2O) n , n = 2-10] found in a number of crystal hosts, have been characterized and display different configurations. However, water clusters in silver(I) sulfonate frameworks have not been studied in detail. It is interesting to note that (H2O)2 dimers exist with OW⋅⋅⋅OW distances of 2.804(4) Å. As shown in Figure , two lattice water molecules in compound 1 arrange themselves to form a hydrogen-bonded water dimer, and this supramolecular water dimer is associated with the L1 ligand by hydrogen bonds. The geometrical parameters of the water dimer and its association with L1 ligand are provided in Table . For comparison, the corresponding values in regular ice, in liquid water, and in the vapor phase are 2.74, 2.85, and 2.98 Å, respectively. Interestingly, two oxygen atoms of the water dimer have different coordination numbers of three and one, respectively. OW2 donates hydrogen bonds to OW1, which in turn donates to carboxylate oxygen atoms. OW1 behaves as an acceptor as well as a donor, while OW2 behaves as a donor only. Therefore, OW1 has a normal three-coordinate  configuration. Two L1 ligands and two water molecules are organized through hydrogen bonds in an approximate quadrangle with four oxygen atoms each at corner.

Compound 1 has undergone great structural changes in contrast to Ag2L1(H2O) (5). Compound 5 shows a three-dimensional (3D) framework, while compound 1 possesses a 1D polymeric structure. The structural changes may be explained by the coordination effect of biim. The coordination modes of the sulfonate and carboxylate groups in 5 are μ5 - and μ2 -bridging, respectively; however, sulfonate and carboxylate groups do not coordinate to silver cations in compound 1. The consequence may be attributed to biim ligands which replace the coordination sites of L1 anion. This also indicates that the interaction between the silver cation and biim is much stronger than that between the silver cation and the L1 anion. In addition, the coordination numbers of silver ions in 5 are 5 and 6, whereas in compound 1, only two- and three-coordinate silver centers exist, respectively.

elements.content: X-ray structure analysis reveals that one kind of crystallographically unique L2 ligand and one kind of crystallographically unique silver ion exist in the structure of compound 2 (Figure ). L2 ligand does not show any bonding actions with silver cations, and only acts as a counteranion as observed in compound 1. Ag1 is two-coordinate, having a perfect linear geometry composed of bonds from two nitrogen atoms from different biim ligands with a Ag(1)−N(2) distance of 2.082(11) Å. Although the amino N atom of L2 ligand is a potential coordinating atom for the silver cation, it did not coordinate to the silver cation in compound 2. Silver cations are bridged by biim ligands to form a infinite zigzag chain just as that observed in compound 1, and the polymeric chains stack to form a 2D sheet (Figure a) and so do L2 ligands (Figure b). The polymeric chains and L2 ligands stack to form the overall structure of 2 (see Figure S2, Supporting Information).

elements.content: Compound 2 shows a 1D polymeric structure rather than a 3D framework found in AgL2 (6). Compared with compound 6, the presence of the biim ligand in compound 2 results in great structural changes. In compound 6, L2 ligand coordinates to four silver atoms with its three sulfonate oxygen atoms and one amino N atom, and each silver cation is four-coordinate by three oxygen atoms from three different L2 ligands and one nitrogen atom from another L2 ligand. In compound 2, however, L2 ligand does not coordinate to silver cations, and only acts as a counteranion. Moreover, the coordination number of silver ion decreases from 4 in 6 to 2 in compound 2. This may be attributed to biim ligands which occupied the coordination sites of the L2 anion as observed in compound 1.

elements.content: X-ray diffraction reveals that compound 3 possesses a dimeric structure as shown in Figure . The 2:1 adduct of β-picoline with silver(I) p-hydroxybenzenesulfonate [Ag(HL3)(Pic)2]·H2O contains a centrosymmetric dimeric unit in which two silver atoms are bridged by two μ2-sulfonate groups. There is one crystallographically unique silver ion in the structure, and each silver cation is coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from two different β-picoline ligands with Ag−N distances being 2.168(3) and 2.163(3) Å, and two oxygen atoms from two HL3 anions with long Ag−O bonds (Ag−O = 2.720−2.788 Å). In addition, a Ag−Ag distance of 3.1080(8) Å is shorter than the van der Waals contact distance for Ag−Ag of 3.40 Å, indicating that Ag−Ag interactions exist within the dimeric unit.

elements.content: X-ray structure analysis reveals that compound 4 possesses one crystallographically unique L3 ligand and two crystallographically unique silver ions in the structure (Figure ). Ag(1) cation is four-coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from two 4,4‘-bipy ligands [Ag(1)−N(1) = 2.182(3) Å, Ag(1)−N(2A) = 2.166(3) Å], one sulfonate oxygen atom [Ag(1)−O(3A) = 2.788 Å], and one aqua ligand [Ag(1)−OW(1) = 2.660 Å]. Ag(2) is two-coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from two 4,4‘-bipy ligands [Ag(2)−N(3) = 2.173(3) Å, Ag(2)−N(4A) = 2.160(4) Å]. Symmetry related Ag(1) and Ag(2) cations are bridged by 4,4‘-bipy ligands to form a 1D chain, respectively (Figure ). Although the hydroxyl group is a potential coordinating group for the silver cation, it did not coordinate to silver cations in compound 4.

elements.content: As shown in Figure , two L3 ligands are linked by a hydrogen bond through the hydrogen atom of the -OH group to form a [L3−H···L3]3- unit. It is interesting to note that (H2O)3 trimers exist in the structure. The geometrical parameters of the water trimer and its association with L3 ligand are provided in Table . Hydrogen-bonding data indicate that the coordinated water molecule (OW1) acting as a donor is hydrogen bonded to the sulfonate oxygen atoms (O3B) and water molecule (OW2A), which in turn donates to O(1C) and OW(3A), which in turn donates to O(4D) and O(2B). The water molecules behave as acceptors as well as donors, while sulfonate oxygen atoms behave completely as acceptors. Water molecules are all three-coordinate as usual. Water trimers and [L3−H···L3]3- units are bridged through the hydrogen-bonding interactions to form a 2D sheet (Figure ). The packing diagram of 4 was shown in Figure S3 of Supporting Information.

elements.content: L1 is a sulfonate-carboxylate ligand containing hydroxyl group, while L2 is a sulfonate ligand containing amino group. Although L1 and L2 have greatly different structural features, compounds 1 and 2 containing biim molecules show a 1D structural feature. Unexpectedly, L1 and L2 sulfonate ligands do not coordinate to silver ions but act as counterions, and amino and hydroxyl groups do not show any hydrogen-bonding interactions. Biim is a strong ligand for a silver ion and prefers to act as a linear μ2-ligand to bridge silver cations to form an infinite zigzag chain structure. The chain of alternate silver ions and biim molecules is the structural feature of the coordination of silver cations with biim molecules. This feature was retained in 1 and 2 perfectly, indicating that the interaction between the silver ion and biim is much stronger than that between the silver cation and the L1 or L2 anion. In this case, biim is the dominant factor to determine the structural feature of the compound even if great structural differences exist between sulfonate ligands.

elements.content: As expected, the HL3 sulfonate ligand shows coordination bonds to silver atoms in compounds 3 and 4, and the -OH group shows hydrogen-bonding interactions in compound 4. However, compounds 3 and 4 show greatly different structural motifs. The differences were generated by the effects of the neutral ligands. Pic is a monodentate ligand with only one nitrogen atom coordinating to a silver atom, while 4,4‘-bipy is a divergent bidentate ligand with two nitrogen atoms coordinating to silver atoms. Therefore, compound 3 shows a discrete dimeric structure, whereas compound 4 has a 1D polymeric structure. These results indicate that the structures of the compounds reported here may be controlled by neutral ligands, and the dimensionalities of the compounds can be adjusted by changing the number of coordinating atoms of the neutral ligand.

elements.content: Recently, the luminescent properties of silver compounds containing CF3SO3 - ions have been reported; however, investigations of silver aromatic sulfonates are seldom. Herein the luminescent properties of compounds 1−3 were studied. The photoluminescent spectra of 1−3 and free ligands are depicted in Figure . Compound 1 exhibits an emission maximum at 407 nm upon excitation at 354 nm. The main emission peaks of H2L1 and biim are at 387 and 398 nm respectively. In contrast to the free ligands, red shifts of 20 and 9 nm have appeared in compound 1. The resemblance between the emission spectrum of compound 1 and those of two free ligands implies that the luminescence of the compound 1 is L12-- or biim-based emission. The emission spectrum of compound 5 shows a main peak at 411 nm with a shoulder peak at 362 nm. In comparison with compound 5, compound 1 contains an extra biim ligand. It is, therefore, conceivable that the coordination of neutral ligands to Ag cations results in the disappearance of the shoulder peak (L → M charge-transfer transition) in compound 1. Compound 2 exhibits an emission maximum at 338 nm upon excitation at 290 nm. HL2 and biim show emission with maxima at 365 and 398 nm, respectively. Compared with the emission of the free ligands HL2 and biim, blue shifts of 27 and 60 nm have been observed upon the formation of compound 2, respectively. The resemblance between the emission spectrum of the compound 2 and that of the free HL2 indicates that the luminescence of the compound 2 is L2--based emission. In comparison with compound 1, a blue shift of 69 nm has been observed in compound 2 due to the replacement of the L12- anion by the L2- anion. Free ligands H2L3 and Pic show emission spectra with maxima at 314 and 358 nm, respectively. Compound 3 shows an emission spectrum with two strong peaks at 480 and 511 nm upon excitation at 332 nm. These two peaks may be attributed to the emission of the HL3- anion and the coordinated Pic molecule. The luminescence of compounds 1−3 should originate from the transitions between the energy levels of sulfonate anion and/or the neutral ligand. The shifts of the emission bands are attributed to both the deprotonation of the sulfonic acid and the coordination action of the sulfonate anion and neutral ligand to silver centers.

elements.content: In summary, four new coordination polymers of silver(I) sulfonates containing neutral ligand were synthesized and characterized. The structural features of the compounds are mainly controlled by the coordination behavior of the neutral ligands. Three of them show 1D polymeric structures that contain polymeric chains of silver ions and neutral ligands, and one shows a dimeric structure. Interestingly, water dimer and water trimer are found in the structures. Moreover, three of the compounds display photoluminescent properties.
elements.clean_text: In summary, four new coordination polymers of silver(I) sulfonates containing neutral ligand were synthesized and characterized. The structural features of the compounds are mainly controlled by the coordination behavior of the neutral ligands. Three of them show 1D polymeric structures that contain polymeric chains of silver ions and neutral ligands, and one shows a dimeric structure. Interestingly, water dimer and water trimer are found in the structures. Moreover, three of the compounds display photoluminescent properties.

Synthesis of [Ag2L1(biim)2]·2H2O (1). To a mixture of H2L1 (0.127 g, 0.5 mmol) and NaOH (0.04 g, 1.0 mmol) in water was added AgNO3 (0.170 g, 1.0 mmol) with constant stirring, to which was added biim (0.096 g, 0.5 mmol) in water. After the sample was stirred for 10 min, the precipitate was dissolved by dropwise addition of aqueous NH3 solution. Colorless crystals were obtained from the filtrate by slow evaporation after standing in the dark for several days (75% yield). Anal. Calcd for C27H35Ag2N8O8S:  C 38.27, H 4.16, N 13.22. found:  C 38.21, H 4.13, N 13.27. IR (KBr, cm-1) 3859(w), 3741(ms), 3443(ms), 2361(vs), 2336(vs), 1700(ms), 1645(ms), 1560(ms), 1515(ms), 1467(w), 1197(w), 673(ms), 565(w), 432(w), 406(ms).

Synthesis of AgL2(biim) (2). To a mixture of HL2 (0.173 g, 1 mmol) and NaOH (0.040 g, 1 mmol) in water was added AgNO3 (0.255 g, 1.5 mmol) with constant stirring, and a white precipitate formed. The precipitate was dissolved by dropwise addition of aqueous NH3 solution, to which was added biim (0.288 g, 1.5 mmol) in 10 mL of ethanol. Colorless crystals were obtained from the filtrate by slow evaporation after standing in the dark room for several days (78% yield). Anal.  Synthesis of AgL2(biim) (2). To a mixture of HL2 (0.173 g, 1 mmol) and NaOH (0.040 g, 1 mmol) in water was added AgNO3 (0.255 g, 1.5 mmol) with constant stirring, and a white precipitate formed. The precipitate was dissolved by dropwise addition of aqueous NH3 solution, to which was added biim (0.288 g, 1.5 mmol) in 10 mL of ethanol. Colorless crystals were obtained from the filtrate by slow evaporation after standing in the dark room for several days (78% yield). Anal. cln_elements.content: Recently, the luminescent properties of silver compounds containing CF3SO3 - ions have been reported; however, investigations of silver aromatic sulfonates are seldom. Herein the luminescent properties of compounds 1−3 were studied. The photoluminescent spectra of 1−3 and free ligands are depicted in Figure . Compound 1 exhibits an emission maximum at 407 nm upon excitation at 354 nm. The main emission peaks of H2L1 and biim are at 387 and 398 nm respectively. In contrast to the free ligands, red shifts of 20 and 9 nm have appeared in compound 1. The resemblance between the emission spectrum of compound 1 and those of two free ligands implies that the luminescence of the compound 1 is L12-- or biim-based emission. The emission spectrum of compound 5 shows a main peak at 411 nm with a shoulder peak at 362 nm. In comparison with compound 5, compound 1 contains an extra biim ligand. It is, therefore, conceivable that the coordination of neutral ligands to Ag cations results in the disappearance of the shoulder peak (L → M charge-transfer transition) in compound 1. Compound 2 exhibits an emission maximum at 338 nm upon excitation at 290 nm. HL2 and biim show emission with maxima at 365 and 398 nm, respectively. Compared with the emission of the free ligands HL2 and biim, blue shifts of 27 and 60 nm have been observed upon the formation of compound 2, respectively. The resemblance between the emission spectrum of the compound 2 and that of the free HL2 indicates that the luminescence of the compound 2 is L2--based emission. In comparison with compound 1, a blue shift of 69 nm has been observed in compound 2 due to the replacement of the L12- anion by the L2- anion. Free ligands H2L3 and Pic show emission spectra with maxima at 314 and 358 nm, respectively. Compound 3 shows an emission spectrum with two strong peaks at 480 and 511 nm upon excitation at 332 nm. These two peaks may be attributed to the emission of the HL3- anion and the coordinated Pic molecule. The luminescence of compounds 1−3 should originate from the transitions between the energy levels of sulfonate anion and/or the neutral ligand. The shifts of the emission bands are attributed to both the deprotonation of the sulfonic acid and the coordination action of the sulfonate anion and neutral ligand to silver centers.
